intro.description:
his tutorial will demonstrate how to turn the Eclipse Browser plug-in into a internalizationalize plug-in.
To learn more about using cheat sheets, click the help button in the top right corner (?).

item.title: Update Preferences
item.description: To internationalize a plug-in we first need to locate any possible string we expose. To do this, preform the following steps.

subitem.label: Open up your workspace preferences window.
Navigate to "Java->Compiler->Errors and Warnings".
Change the value of "Non-externalized strings (missing/unused $NON_NLS$ tag)" to Warning.
Navigate to "Plug-in Development->Compilers".
Change the value of "Usage of non-externalized strings" to Warning. Press "OK". When prompted about a rebuild, select "Yes".

item.title: Externalize UI Strings in java code
item.description: To run your plug-in in different languages, you will need to store UI strings in a properties file. This will allow you to load a different properties file for each language. Follow the steps below to externalize your UI strings found in your java code:

subitem.label: Right click on the "org.eclipse.browser" project and select "Source->Externalized Strings..." from the context menu.
Double click on "2 in /org.eclipse.browser/src/org/eclipse/browser/application/BrowserActionBarAdvisor.java"
Click on the first entry in the Key column. Type "file". Click on the second entry in the Key column. Type "help".
Press "Next" to see the changes which will be made.
Press "Finish"

item.title: Externalize UI Strings in Plug-in markup
item.description: To run your plug-in in different languages, you will need to store UI strings in a properties file. This will allow you to load a different properties file for each language. Follow the steps below to externalize your UI strings found in your plug-in markup:

subitem.label: Right click on the plugin.xml file in the "org.eclipse.browser" project and Select "PDE Tools->Externalize Strings..." from the context menu.

Select "plugin.xml" under "org.eclipse.browser" in the table on the left. Notice the non-externalized key from your plugin.xml are displayed under "Strings to externalize". Press "Next" to see the changes which will be made.
Press "Finish"

item.title: Enable different icons for different locales
item.description: To enable your plug-in to provide different icons for different locales, preform the following steps:

subitem.label: Right click on the plugin.xml file in the "org.eclipse.browser" project and select "PDE Tools->Oraganize Manifests..."
Check the "Prefix icon paths in the plug-in extensions with an $nl$ segement"
Press "Next" to see the changes which will be performed.
Press "Finish"

item.title: Create nl fragments for different locales
item.description: To create language fragments for different locales, perform the following steps:

subitem.label: Select "File->New->Project..." from the main menu to bring up the Import wizard. Expand the "Plug-in Development" category, and choose "Fragment Project". Press "Next".
Type "org.eclipse.browser.nl1" for the Project name. Uncheck "Create a Java Project" since this fragment will not contribute java code. Press "Next".
Enter "Browser NL1 Fragment" in the Fragment name. Press the "Browse" button. Select the "org.eclipse.browser" plug-in and select "OK". Press "Finish".

item.title: Externalize Bundle-Name in fragment
item.description: Follow these steps to resolve the warnings in the new fragment project:

subitem.label: Right click on the MANIFEST.MF file in the "org.eclipse.browser.nl1" project and select "PDE Tools->Externalize Strings..." from the context menu.
Press "Next" to see the changes which will be made.
Press "Finish"

item.title: Add language specific content
item.description: Properties files containing language specific strings must be created for each locale. Perform the following steps to add language specific content

subitem.label: Select "File->New->Other..." from the main menu to bring up the New wizard. Expand the "General" category, and choose "File". Press "Next".
In the "New File wizard", select the "org.eclipse.browser.nl1" project as the parent folder, then input "plugin_es.properties" into the "File name" text box. Press "Finish".
Enter "view.name.0 = Spanish Eclipse Browser" into the file.
Select "File->Save" from the main menu.
Select "File->New->Other..." from the main menu to bring up the New wizard. Expand the "General" category, and choose "Folder". Press "Next".
In the "New Folder wizard", select the "org.eclipse.browser.nl1" project as the parent folder, then input "org/eclipse/browser/application/" into the "Folder name" text box. Press "Finish".
Select "File->New->Other..." from the main menu to bring up the New wizard. Expand the "General" category, and choose "File". Press "Next".

In the "New File wizard", select the "org.eclipse.browser.nl1/org/eclipse/browser/application/" folder as the parent folder, then input "messages_es.properties" into the "File name" text box. Press "Finish".
Enter the following two lines: "BrowserActionBarAdvisor.file=&Archivo BrowserActionBarAdvisor.help=A&yuda" into the file.
Select "File->Save" from the main menu.

item.title: Launch plug-in with a different language
item.description: Perform the following steps to lauch the Browser plug-in and nl fragment with a different language:

subitem.label: Open up your workspace preferences window. Navigate to Plug-in Development > Target Platform.
Select the "Environment" tab. Change the Locale combo to "es - Spanish"
Press "OK"
Open the "browser.product" product definition file in the "org.eclipse.browser" project.
On the "Configuration" tab of the product editor, press "Add Required Plug-ins" in the "Plug-ins and Fragments" section.
Save the "browser.product" file via "File->Save" from the main menu.

On the "Overview" page of the product editor, click the "Launch the product" hyperlink under the "Testing" heading. Notice how the menus are now in spanish and the browser name is now "Spanish Eclipse Browser".
Select "File->Exit" from the main menu to close the second Eclipse instance.
